perturbation.original_text: 4.3 Terms of Use. Throughout the Term, Licensee shall have in effect and maintain accessible on the Licensee Site and Related Media website terms of use ("Terms of Use") and privacy policy ("Privacy Policy") on which use of the Licensee Site and Related Media, including the Licensed Content, is expressly conditioned, and which in form and substance are reasonably acceptable to Licensor.
perturbation.changed_text: 4.3 Terms of Use. Throughout the Term, Licensee shall have in effect and maintain accessible on the Licensee Site and Related Media website terms of use (“Terms of Use”) on which use of the Licensee Site and Related Media, including the Licensed Content, is expressly conditioned.
perturbation.explanation: By removing the requirement to maintain a 'privacy policy' reasonably acceptable to Licensor, the contract omits a key consumer protection measure. Many jurisdictions, including Nevada and Washington (where the Licensee is based), have laws requiring websites to have clear and accessible privacy policies, especially when collecting user data. Removing the obligation to maintain a privacy policy that is reasonably acceptable creates a legal risk for non-compliance with privacy laws such as the California Consumer Privacy Act (CCPA) or the Washington Privacy Act, as it is no longer guaranteed that user data will be handled according to legal standards, potentially affecting users in California, Washington, and other states with similar laws, given the nationwide scope of internet accessibility.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California Consumer Privacy Act (CCPA); Washington Privacy Act; Nevada Revised Statutes 603A

perturbation.original_text: 11.12 Dispute Resolution. In the event of a dispute arising out of this Agreement, the parties shall first negotiate in good faith in an effort to reach a settlement of the dispute. If having negotiated in good faith, the parties are unable to resolve their dispute, the parties shall submit the dispute to binding arbitration by a single arbitrator. The arbitration shall be governed by the Commercial Rules of Arbitration of the American Arbitration Association. The arbitration shall take place at an agreed location, or if the parties cannot agree on a venue in Reno, Nevada or Vancouver, BC, as determined by the flip of a coin. The arbitrator shall have jurisdiction over the conduct of discovery prior to the hearing. Notwithstanding the foregoing, nothing in this Section 11.13 shall be construed to prohibit either party from seeking appropriate injunctive or other equitable relief in a court of competent jurisdiction.
perturbation.changed_text: 11.12 Dispute Resolution. In the event of a dispute arising out of this Agreement, the parties shall first negotiate in good faith in an effort to reach a settlement of the dispute. If having negotiated in good faith, the parties are unable to resolve their dispute, the parties shall submit the dispute to binding arbitration by a single arbitrator. The arbitration shall be governed by the Commercial Rules of Arbitration of the American Arbitration Association. The arbitration shall take place at an agreed location, or if the parties cannot agree on a venue in Reno, Nevada or Vancouver, BC, as determined by the flip of a coin. The arbitrator shall have jurisdiction over the conduct of discovery prior to the hearing.
perturbation.explanation: By removing the phrase 'Notwithstanding the foregoing, nothing in this Section 11.13 shall be construed to prohibit either party from seeking appropriate injunctive or other equitable relief in a court of competent jurisdiction,' the modified contract now *prohibits* either party from seeking injunctive or other equitable relief, even in cases of intellectual property theft or breach of contract. This violates principles of contract law that protect a party's right to seek equitable relief. Injunctive relief is a crucial remedy to prevent ongoing harm that cannot be compensated with money damages. This deletion is particularly problematic considering the subject matter of the agreement - content licensing where immediate action might be necessary to protect content rights. Nevada law recognizes the right to seek injunctive relief in contract disputes, so this clause directly contradicts that.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Nevada Revised Statutes regarding equitable remedies and injunctive relief

perturbation.original_text: 11.13 Attorneys' Fees. In the event that any action, suit, or other legal or administrative proceeding is instituted or commenced by either party hereto against the other party arising out of this Agreement, the prevailing party shall be entitled to recover its reasonable attorneys' fees and court costs from the non-prevailing party.
perturbation.changed_text: 11.13 Attorneys' Fees. In the event that any action, suit, or other legal or administrative proceeding is instituted or commenced by either party hereto against the other party arising out of this Agreement, each party shall bear their own attorneys' fees and court costs.
perturbation.explanation: By changing the clause to state 'each party shall bear their own attorneys' fees and court costs,' the contract eliminates the prevailing party's right to recover attorney's fees, even if the other party is proven to be wrong. The attorney's fee clause is a critical component of many commercial contracts, providing an incentive for parties to act in good faith and avoid frivolous litigation. While Nevada law generally follows the 'American Rule' (each party pays their own fees), there are statutory exceptions and contractual agreements to the contrary are generally enforceable. By altering the fee provision, the contract disincentivizes the Licensor from suing the Licensee for breach of contract.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Principles of Nevada contract law regarding attorney's fee provisions.
